title: Measuring Obesity
content: Superior tools for measuring obesity at the individual level include DEXA scans which provide 4 points of information: 1) % body fat 2) Visceral fat (VAT, visceral adipose tissue) 3) Bone mineral density 4) Appendicular Lean Mass Index, a measure of muscle mass. It also provides information about subcutaneous fat, but that doesn’t seem to matter because it is incredibly genetic and relatively uncoupled from metabolic health. VAT, the visceral adipose tissue seems to be much more tightly correlated to what we see when we look at more sophisticated biomarkers of insulin sensitivity and metabolic health, and any evidence of liver fat.

title: Limitations of BMI
content: BMI offers little insight, relative to other tools. It’s the least bad tool available to get massive data sets and broad assessments on, for understanding what’s going on at the population level. However, there are concerns about the futility of BMI measurement in some populations.

title: Editorial Contributions
content: Contributed to many editorial boards and is currently an associate editor or statistical editor for Obesity; International Journal of Obesity; Nutrition Today; Obesity Reviews; Public Library of Science (PLOS) Genetics; Surgery for Obesity and Related Diseases (SOARD), and American Journal of Clinical Nutrition. Founding Field Chief Editor of Frontiers in Genetics.

title: Research Interests
content: Research interests include obesity and nutrition, quantitative genetics, clinical trials, statistical and research methodology, and research rigor and integrity.
